Nnrrh I'liiiip Tpihu explrm HHS 11, f« Wehntor, Tukmuiili Turin wnirm U»4fi STAFF Mlhh Nellie M, Carey, Hxeentive Secretary Mrs, Dorothy W, LowHeiihop, ,-lsd\lanl Secretary and Reference Librarian Mldfl Jflflnlo Rohertflon, Aulttant in charge of School and Community Loans Mlbb Knthryn L, Buck, Calaloger Miss Loriin CollliiH, Stenographer Mrs, Katharine Stcrkcl, Part time Typist Boyd Elliot, Part time Shipping Clerk Ralph Larson, Part time Shipping Clerk Office i Room 1508, Stato Capitol Building, Lincoln Hours: 8:00 to 12:00 and 1:00 to 5:00. Closes at 12:00 on Saturday

REPORT OF THE NEBRASKA PUBLIC LIBRARY COMMISSION December 1, 1940 to November 30, 1942 In the period covered by this report libraries have been faced with the opportunity and responsibility of providing and promoting the reading of thought provoking books on all aspects of current problems and their his - torical background which would contribute to a better understanding of the war and its causes, our own country's relation to it, what living in a democracy means, the kind of a peace we want, and post-war problems. Immediately after the United States entered the war the Library Com - mission set up a War Information Center to make readily accessible books, pamphlets and other material which have a bearing on the war. Each month the Commission receives from the United States Information Service, Office of Government Reports, packets of up-to-date information on such subjects as air raid precautions, salvage, nutrition, housing, first aid, etc., which sup - plement the regular collection in the Library Commission and this is all available for loan to anyone in the state. The material has been used by those setting up defense programs, by business men, club women, teachers and others. In the purchase of new books emphasis has been placed on books on wartime and peacetime issues, with duplication of important titles as neces - sary to meet requests. Books especially in demand have been those which tell about various branches of the armed service, opportunities and training for war industries, books abut the countries involved in the war and reports of eye witnesses of battles. The following are typical of the topics on which information has been requested: insignia of the United States; the Junior Red Cross; effect of the war on missions; the Alaska highway; songs of the armed forces; children in the post-war world; noted refugees in America; guerrilla warfare, and life in the army. All libraries in Nebraska participated in a nation-wide Victory Book Campaign to raise 10,000,000 books for the armed forces. The executive secretary of the Library Commission served as a member of the executive committee which helped plan and organize the campaign in Nebraska, and also served as the liaison librarian for the Seventh Service Command. The Library Commission was the collection center for the Capitol building. In Nebraska over 100,000 books were collected, about half of which were suit- 9

able ior the men in the war service. Books which would be of interest to women and children were sent to VV.P.A. recreation centers in war industry areas. The war has placed additional emphasis on the education of adults. The Library Commission works with many groups and organizations interested in some phase of adult education. The executive secretary of the Com - mission is serving a second term as secretary of the Nebraska Council of Adult Relocation, and represents the Nebraska Library Association on the State Advisory Council for the National Citizenship Education Program. She is also library adviser for the Committee on Home Economics Education Through Libraries. Close contact is maintained with the chairman of the library department of the Nebraska Federation of Women's Clubs and of the.- Nebraska Congress of Parents and Teachers. During the last few years the rural Project Clubs under the direction of the extension service of the Nebraska College of Agriculture have carried mi ji directed reading program. Reading lists have been prepared by the Library Commission and books on the lists loaned to those who are unable to secure them through local libraries. Reports from 4,624 women enrolled in 1041-42 in the reading project showed that they had read 36,17s books. Dictionaries, encyclopedias, the World Almanac, and other reference hooks are in constant use by employees in other state departments. Books on >m'ial welfare problems ;ire in demand by those workir.g in the State Assist - ance Department and by those preparing lor the merit examinations. Col - lections of books have been loaned on request to several of the state institu - tions. Books from the Library Commission have been borrowed by schools, • ¦rsanizations. or individuals in each of the ninety-three counties in the state during the hiennium. Only .so'/r of the population of Nebraska have local library service and many rural communities depend entirely on the Library Commission for books. The N'ehraska Library Association is a professional organization of li - brarians, trustees and others interested in libraries. The Library Commission and the Library Association work together for the extension and improve - ment of library service in the state. Right district library meetings were held in the spring of 1041 with an attendance of 337. Due to the rubber shortage and war conditions no district meetings were held in 1942. Several members ,i the Library Commission and of the staff attended the state library meeting in Grand Island October 16-18, 1041 and in Omaha October 1-3, 1942. Staff members served on a number of committees, and also compiled and edited a directory of all the librarians in the state and a handbook of the Library Association. Ninety visits to libraries were made during the biennium to confer with librarians and library trustees on special problems of organization, adminis- 10

tration and extension of service. Assistance was also given through cor - respondence and through the loan of books and pamphlets on cataloging, per - sonnel, library laws, county libraries, organization of school libraries, etc. The Library Commission maintains free placement service for librarians and has many calls from libraries in need of trained or experienced librar - ians. - There is at present a shortage of qualified people available in the state for library positions. Through the Union Catalogue which began functioning in 1940 it is possible for librarians to find the location of any of the 1,677,000 volumes in 28 of the largest university, college, public and special libraries in Ne - braska. These books are available to any resident of the state for consulta - tion in the library owning the books, or in many cases through loans to the local libraries. The Union Catalogue is in charge of the cataloger at the Li - brary Commission. A state-wide W.P.A. library project which was sponsored by the Li - brary Commission was discontinued in February, 1942, except for two demon - strations of county library service. A demonstration began in Phelps County in November, 1940 with the Holdrege Carnegie Library and the Phelps County Commissioners as the local sponsors. At the general election on November 3, 1942 a majority of the voters authorized the establishment of a tax-supported county library. A similar demonstration began in Lancaster County in September, 1941 with the Lincoln City Library as the local sponsor. The proposal to establish a county library Inst by a small vote. Voters in two other counties. Grant and Arthur, also authorized the county commissioners to levy a tax for the support of a library. Members of the women's clubs in these counties backed the campaign. Adams County, having voted in 1940 to establish a county library as the result of a demonstration, operated in rg4i with N.Y.A. and local assistance and in 1942 began receiving an appropriation from the county. Two library laws were amended by, the legislature in 1941. Legislative Bill No. 37 amended Sec. 51-40T, C.S. Supp. 1939 to provide that only those people living outside the cities, villages, or townships already maintaining a public library by public tax shall vote on the question of establishing county or regional libraries. Legislative Bill No. 427 amended Sec. 51-205, C.S. 1929 to permit the library board of any city, village, township, or county to sell any real estate owned by the library board or by the public library which is not used for library purposes. The Library Commission receives noteworthy gifts of collections of new books from three sources. Books on family life are given by the Ne - braska Home Economics Association as a memorial to Eva Morse. Twenty - seven books were added in 1041-42. 11

A number of publishers contribute recent books for children for a traveling library exhibit. During 1041-42, 267 books were received from this ¦oiirce. Eighty-one adult and children's books on international relations were isiven to the Commission by the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace. There was one change in the membership of the Library Commission during the bieunium. Mrs. David Xorthup of Omaha was appointed in June, 1942 to succeed Mrs. C. W. Hevner of Franklin, whose term expired. Mr. 11. L. Webster of Tekamah. was reappointed in June, 1941 for another five >car term. 12

SUMMARY OF STATISTICS Volumes in Library Volumes in library December 1, 1940. 57,718 Volumes added by purchase and gift 8,565 Volumes worn out and discarded 3,412 Volumes in library December I, 1942 62,871 Record of Loans Requests Borrowers Filled Volumes Groups of residents 444 32,463 Public Schools 1,913 28,716 Schools 1,955 87,976 Other organizations 51 4,196 Study Clubs 2,640 6,466 Individuals 14,034 33,481 Total 21,037 193,298 Expenditures Expend. Abbott 12 4.669 401 9,293 11.2 475 28 512 214 165 50.1 .61 SReport for 1941 ITownship library 'Includes township population Total volumes reported 1,462.10.3 Total borrowers reported 278,821 Total circulation reported 3,712,20(i Total receipts including balance reported $ 430,285 Total expenditures reported ..$ 374,859 24

LIBRARIES NOT TAX-SUPPORTED There are in Nebraska a large number of libraries not included in the list of tax-supported libraries. These libraries are usually sponsored and maintained by some club or organization. Some of these libraries receive a small amount from the town and in other cases rooms, heat and light are furnished. Changes in librarians are frequent due to the fact that many of them serve without pay.
